headline: A Supreme Court Redistricting Clean Up
author: The Editorial Board
sentences:
Mr. Evers embraced “just the sort of uncritical majority-minority district maximization that we have expressly rejected.”
In a dissent, Justices Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan called the majority’s ruling in response to a petition for a stay “unprecedented.” But Mr. Evers’s racial gerrymander was egregious, and lower-court judges keep misapplying Court precedents.

Mr. Evers argued that seven majority-minority districts were necessary to comply with Section 2 of the VRA, which requires that minorities have equal opportunity “to participate in the political process and to elect representatives of their choice.” The Court’s confusing Gingles precedent interpreted this as a prohibition on minority vote dilution.

Its order remands the map to the state high court, underscoring that a new one “must comply with our equal protection jurisprudence.”
The liberal dissenters are right that the Court’s redistricting precedents are “hazy,” a point Chief Justice John Roberts made last month in a VRA challenge to Alabama’s House map.

Wisconsin’s high court “focused exclusively on proportionality” and failed to consider “whether a race-neutral alternative that did not add a seventh majority-black district would deny black voters equal political opportunity,” the Supreme Court majority writes.

The map intentionally created seven majority-black state Assembly districts—one more than under its current map—which would have likely assured at least one more safe Democratic seat.
The Court’s opinion in the Wisconsin case is a step toward clearing up this haze for lower courts, which are increasingly being asked to wade into this political thicket.
Gingles and “its progeny have engendered considerable disagreement and uncertainty regarding the nature and contours of a vote dilution claim,” the Chief noted.
Tony Evers addresses a joint session of the Legislature during the governor's State of the State speech at the state Capitol in Madison, Wis., Feb. 15.
“Under the Equal Protection Clause, districting maps that sort voters on the basis of race ‘are by their very nature odious,’” the majority writes.
The Court’s unsigned order in Wisconsin Legislature v. Wisconsin Elections Commission skewers the Governor and the Wisconsin Supreme Court.
But Gingles also laid out numerous pre-conditions for creating these districts to ensure states aren’t invidiously sorting voters by race.
